Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: The Teen Career Pathway: A Serious Game for Job Skills
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase 1 Project will systematically develop, test, and revise a video game. Emerging technologies, such as educational videogames, have the potential to increase the accessibility of learning materials, promote readiness and knowledge of employment options, and improve students' attitudes toward full-time employment. Unfortunately, the lack of an accessible, coherent career planning system in the United States has left many high school students unprepared to meet the rigorous demands associated with being college and career ready. This project will teach critical life, social, and academic skills related to a career in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) aligning with NSF's mission supporting and education for all fields of fundamental science and engineering. This project is designed to enhance student learning, reduce school costs, and increase the efficacy of transition plans, which are mandated for every student with a disability under Federal law. The game aligns with Common Core Standards and the Universal Design for Learning framework. While this project will be designed for students with disabilities, it is assumed the highly accessible career preparation software will also meet a critical need for other students at risk of learning failure or students without disabilities.


This project is a critical component of a comprehensive product line that will provide adolescents with virtual career training. During the project, participants will experience three mini-games related to their daily living skills, a "day in the life" of a person in a STEM career, and social skills acquisition and how those allow individuals to interpret the culture. A virtual mentor coaches the student to make choices that will lead to career advancement & explains the hierarchy of jobs within the chosen career. The virtual mentor also provides financial advice throughout the daily living games, modeling exemplary fiscal management and reinforcing decisions that have a high likelihood of leading to financial stability. The project team will build, test, analyze, and revise the three alpha versions of the mini-games and then compile the revisions into a beta version of the game. Initial friends and family tests of the alpha builds will include qualitative evaluation using observations and interviews. This will be followed with beta testing in public schools using a mixed methods design. Beta testing will include students with and without disabilities in grades six through nine, special education and general education teachers, counselors and parents.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Teen Career Pathway: An analysis of a career preparation video game for students with disabilities and other at-risk populations 

This material is based on work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant number 1519717. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

Transition planning is essential for preparing students to be college and career ready. An essential component of this planning is the identification of realistic career opportunities. Unfortunately, this process is often costly and time consuming. Emerging technologies, such as educational video games, have the potential to increase the accessibility of learning materials, promote 21st Century skills, and improve students’ attitudes toward full-time employment (Access STEM, 2008). Unfortunately, the lack of an accessible, coherent career planning system in the United States has left many high school students unprepared to meet the rigorous demands associated with being college and career ready (Choitz, Soares, & Pleasant, 2010). Leddy (2010) noted only 5% of students with disabilities enter the STEM workforce even though their individual attributes often lend themselves to success in these career paths. The present study examined the potential of a video game to provide career exploration activities for students with a range of disabilities (n=70), English language learners (n=49), and students without disabilities (n=327) across a mix of special education and general education classrooms.  Findings suggest the software can provide students with virtual career experiences at a reduced cost. In addition, career software has the potential to reduce time spent in placements where the student has a limited chance of success.

One promising practice to enhance career preparation is the use of individualized learning plans (ILPs). Thirty-five states now mandate ILPs as a means to provide students with explicit pathways to postsecondary education and career goals (Solberg, Wills, & Osmond, 2012). ILPs are strategic planning tools that help students and families align high school coursework with career aspirations. Research suggests that students with ILPs, who control their career exploration, planning and management, are likely to become confident learners who regularly attend school, actively set goals, and attain higher grades (Solberg, Howard, Gresham, & Carter, 2012).

Other research indicates ILPs lead to (Budge, Solberg, Phelps, Haaksen, and Durham, 2010):

?      Increase perceptions of the relevance of education in students’ lives

?      Students’ selecting a plan of study that aligns with their career goals

?      More rigorous course selection

?      Increased communication between school and home environments

Many schools have expressed difficulty in fully implementing ILPs because of limited resources and time constraints. The Teen Career Pathway is designed to address this critical need and increase postsecondary and workforce readiness by immersing students in a virtual “day in the life” of a career professional. The virtual workplace experience provides a unique platform on which students learn life, social, and career specific content and skills.
